Besides that, they have slowly grown, increased the number of customers and their products.

Because of her willingness to succeed, the coordinator is Mirla. She has a small convenience store located in a room of her house. She has been doing this activity for 5 years with a lot of dedication since it is her family's source of income. She works 12 hours in her store to be able to provide better service to her customers. 

The purpose of the loan is to invest in working capital and stock her business with products such as: rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, detergents, juices, sodas, matches, flour, vegetables, “tiste” (a beverage made of cornmeal, cocoa, sugar and annatto), ice, candies, “meneitos” (cheese puffs), etc. so that in the near future she can obtain better income.

The “Panales No 2” communal bank is grateful to the Kiva lenders who help people of limited resources and poor countries like Nicaragua have dignified work.

loans.use: to stock her convenience store with products such as: rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, detergents, juices, sodas, matches, flour, vegetables, "tiste" (a beverage made of cornmeal, cocoa, sugar and annatto), etc.

loans.name: Sabetan

texts.en:
Sabetan is a 49-year-old lady who lives in Falakata of West Bengal. She is a mother of two daughters. Her daughters are studying in different grades in the local village school. Sabetan is illiterate but knows how to sign her name. But she is willing to provide her daughters a good education so that her daughters do not face any obstacle in receiving education. 

Sabetan’s husband has been associated with agricultural activities for many years. His earnings are hardly enough to cover the educational expenses of their daughters after meeting the household costs for their family. 

Sabetan’s elder daughter, 17-year-old Anora, is now studying in grade 8 and is very serious about her studies. She aims to become a Nurse in future.  Now she needs the help of private tuition to score good marks in her examination otherwise she cannot proceed further. 

Sabetan learned about BJS (Kiva’s partner) and applied for a loan for her daughter’s uninterrupted education. With the loan amount she will pay the private tuition fee and buy necessary educational articles for her daughter Anora. 

Sabetan and her daughter Anora are very much grateful to Kiva and BJS for this loan. They give hearty thanks to the lenders.

loans.use: To pay the tuition fees and buy necessary articles for her daughter’s educational purposes.

loans.name: Julian Alberto

texts.es:
Julián es un hombre con 27 años de edad, trabajador y humilde, que día a día busca los recursos necesarios para salir adelante con su hijo de 3 años.

Después de quedarse sin empleo, su deseo es abrir su primer negocio, un almacén con variedad de productos para todo tipo de personas.
Solicita un préstamo en la Corporación Interactuar el cual lo invertirá en la compra de ropa, lociones, cremas, esmaltes, juguetería y otros.

Su meta es seguir creciendo como familia y empresario, poder brindarle a su hijo una buena estabilidad económica y mejor calidad de vida.

Impacta la vida de este empresario, haga un préstamo.
texts.en:
Julian is a 27 year old man who is hard-working and modest. On a daily basis he seeks the necessary means to get ahead with his 3 year old son.

After becoming unemployed, his wish is to open his first business. A warehouse with a variety of products for all types of people.

He is asking for a loan from the Interactuar Corporation, which he will invest in buying clothes, lotions, creams, nail polishes, toys and other things.

His goal is to grow in terms of his family and business, to be able to provide his child with economic stability and a better quality of life.

Change the life of this businessman, make a loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes, lotions, creams, nail polishes, toys, and other things

loans.name: Maa Saraswati Shg-B Group

texts.en:
Maa Saraswati Shg-B (Self-Help Group B) is comprised of three women from a village in the Keonjhar district in Odisha. They formed a group to help themselves to share their problems and solve their problems among themselves. One of them is Saraswati, who was selected as the President of this Group. The lady standing in middle in the photo is Saraswati. Saraswati is 31 years old and lives with her two children. She hopes to educate her children in a good school. She has three acres of land in her village and she is using her land to grow sugarcane. Her parent is supporting her in this activity. 

Saraswati has requested this loan with her group members. A part of it will help her to purchase the required resources for sugarcane cultivation. She says a portion of the loan will help her to purchase sugarcane plants, fertilizers, and insecticides, and to cover operational expenses like labor charges. 

Saraswati, along with her group members, says, "Thank you Kiva for this kind help and support".

loans.use: to purchase sugarcane plants, fertilizers, and insecticides

loans.name: Bharati

texts.en:
43-year-old Bharati lives in a small village called Chuakhola in Falakata. She has two children (one son and one daughter). Her husband runs a cycle repairing shop. His income is too low to bear the education as well as household costs of his family. Bharati’s son completed his master's degree, now he works in the police department on daily wages basis. 

Her 18-year-old daughter Monika is studying in grade 10. Next year she will take her secondary board examination. Thus she needs guidance of good tutors and study materials. Monika is trying her level best to score good marks in her board examination. Both Bharati and her husband have great expectations of their only daughter, but they can't afford her huge educational expenses.

Hence Bharati is requesting a loan from BJS (a Kiva partner) to bear the educational expenses of her daughter. She plans to use the loan money to pay school and tuition fees and buy necessary study materials for her daughter. The loan will help this bright young girl continue her education without any obstacles.

Bharati and Monika (in the photo) are grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's educational expenses.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas, 24, is married to Bephon and has two children. She has been a hotel worker for the last two years, which earns her 6,000 KES a month. She now makes and sells mandazi (a type of sweet fried bread like a donut) and chapatti for both customers and her family.

Dorcas has applied for her first loan of 25,000 KES from Kiva's field partner VisionFund Kenya to buy more ingredients such as cooking oil and baking flour for her products. She plans to save her profits to buy a dairy cow for milk production and repay the loan. Her hope is to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients to make mandazi and chapatti to sell.

loans.name: Sokun

texts.en:
Sokun, 30, is a married man who lives in a small community of Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia and is a father of three children. To make a living and support his family, he manages and operates a farming business on a small farmland which is located near his house. On his farmland, he grows rice and sells his agricultural product to the local dealers. On average, he can generate an earning of USD 3.00 per day. 

He is now applying for a KIVA loan via HKL to buy a construction material to build a house. This loan will allow him to experience owning convenient house. He is thankful to all lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: to build a house

loans.name: Thank Lenders -N4Minhthắngmlộc Group

texts.en:
Mrs Loán is 62 years old and she is married.  She has operated a food stall/restaurant selling fish for more than 10 years.Loán lives in Hau Loc district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover this region often suffered by natural disasters such as storms because it is near the sea. 

The main hardship that Loán faces is lack of capital.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more sea food to resell.

In 2009, Loán joined Thanh Hoa microfinance institution to improve her  business. Loán has successfully repaid 7 loans from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution.
With her business profit, Loán hopes to build a new house, for her family to be healthy and happy and to maintain  a successful business.

loans.use: to purchase more sea food to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for several packs of processed and frozen meats to sell.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.es: Desde niña Felicia fue motivada por sus padres para que trabajara de forma independiente,  consejo que acato e inició su propio negocio de venta de prendas de vestir y  productos para el cuidado personal que comercializa por intermedio de catálogos especializados.  Su meta a futuro es abrir un almacén, sin embargo considera que debe continuar trabajando como lo está haciendo, dedicada y comprometida, para así subir un peldaño más en su vida comercial.  Todos los días está dispuesta a encontrar oportunidades de ventas entre sus clientes, pero su insuficiente capital no le permite responder a la cobertura total de clientes a los que le puede vender.  En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo que invertirá en la compra de prendas de vestir y promociones de productos de la oferta del catálogo.  Con esta inversión podrá incrementar sus ventas y con ello sus ganancias.  Felicia de 39 años, es madre de dos niños menores de edad a quienes desea ofrecerles una excelente educación y bienestar con el fruto de su actividad comercial.
texts.en:
Felicia is 29 years old, she is mother to two young children to whom she wishes to provide and excellent education and wellbeing from the fruits of her labour. Since she was a small child Felicia was motivated by her parents to work independently, advice she followed and set up her own business selling clothing garments and personal care products which she sells via specialist catalogues. 

Her future goal is to open a warehouse, however she knows that she must continue working as she is at the moment, dedicated and committed, to climb a step further in her commercial life. 

Every day, she is looking to find sales opportunities, but her insufficient capital doesn't allow her to cover all of the clients to whom she could sell. 

At the moment she is applying for a Kiva loan, her first loan from the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, which she will invest in buying clothes, and promoting her catalogue products. With this investment she will be able to increase her sales and therefore her earnings.

loans.use: to buy clothing garments and to promote catalogue offer products.

loans.name: Sheila Marie

texts.en:
Sheila Marie is 27 years old with one children.  She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 9500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks like soap, sardines, eggs, coffee, noodles, etc. to sell.

Sheila Marie has borrowed and paid 2 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 1 years and also earns an income from motorcycle transport.

Sheila Marie aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks like soap, sardines, eggs, coffee, noodles, etc. to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for One Fresh Life Toilet.

loans.name: Chandramani

texts.en:
Chandramani is a rural woman from Falakata. She is a 48-year-old married lady and a mother of one daughter.  She did not have any formal education and only can sign her name but she is very eager to give her only daughter the best education she deserves. 

Chandramani's only daughter Doli is 21 years old. She is studying in B.A. (Bachelor of Arts) 2nd year in Falakata College. She is a hard-working student and wants to be a teacher in the future.  She needs proper guidance to excel and prepare for competitive exams. Chandramani's husband is a farmer by trade. His income covers the household expenses but cannot afford the whole education cost of their only daughter. Sometimes they cannot even provide necessary books for their daughter. As such, providing her (Doli) with private coaching is too difficult for them to manage. 

So to solve this problem Chandramani had applied for an educational loan from BJS (Kiva's partner). The loan amount will be utilized for purchasing her daughter's necessary textbooks, paying all college fees, and for enrolling her in a private coaching class. Chandramani is hopeful that the loan will help her daughter to go one step closer to her goals.

Chandramani and Doli (as seen in the photo) express their gratitude towards their generous lenders.

loans.use: To cover all the education-related costs of her daughter.

loans.name: Olsi

texts.en:
Olsi will use the loan that he is requesting from you to buy fertilizer for the agricultural plantations, some of them seen in the background. 

Olsi is a 26-year-old, single man, living in the rural part of southeastern Albania and he is planning to marry soon. He’s been doing agriculture for a living for so many years, since he turned 16, as per his statement. His family owns some agricultural land where they plant and also sell in large quantities, mainly dried beans, potatoes, onions, and garlic.

”It’s tough doing agriculture, especially in the primitive way we do it. It’s exhaustive and the weather conditions make it extremely hard. We have the longest and coldest winters in Albania and in the summer you are all day out in the fields, with the sun burning your back and face, even though we try to shield it with straw hats,” said Olsi during the interview.  

In addition to this activity, he runs a little bar-café in the village of his residence.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry is 53 years old, married and supports a family of five children. For the past twelve years he has been operating a motorcycle transport business and earns approximately 12,000 KES a month.

Henry has applied for his first loan of 25,000 KES from Kiva's field partner VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production and so increase his income. He plans to use his profits to educate his children and is always working toward financial stability.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production and so increase his income.

loans.name: Vazgen

texts.en:
Vazgen owns a big truck, through which he organizes transportation of different export goods to neighbouring country,. He makes 4 trips during the month and gathers income which is vital for his family's living. Vazgen lives with his wife and two daughters (16 and 13 years old). 

He has now applied for this loan to purchase  4 tires for his truck to continue transportation service. The current tires are too old and need to be changed so Vazgen will able to organize his coming trips for this month. 

He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. Vazgen hopes to receive lenders' support and develop his transportation business so his business will be continued.

loans.use: to pay for new 4 tires for his truck to continue transportation service

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence is 59 years old, married and supports a family of four children. For the past eleven years he has operated a small general store, which earns him approximately 8,000 KES a month.

Lawrence has applied for his first loan of 25,000 KES through Kiva's field partner VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production and sales and use the anticipated profits to educate his children. Financial stability is always a primary concern of his.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production and use the anticipated profits to educate his children.

loans.name: Arben

texts.en:
Arben who is 45 years old and married has been doing livestock for the past two years; he wants to invest on 8 goats now and your loan will help him immensely.  
“I would love to expand the livestock. I see it very profitable thanks to all Albanians who consume large amounts of dairy products. There are no other opportunities to make a living. My wife is a baby sitter and makes about $300/month, but that’s almost nothing; it is the rent of one-bedroom apartment, that’s all. I would very much appreciate any financial help I receive from lenders, ” said Arben.  

Currently he has 80 chickens and 30 little hens, 10 turkeys, 3 goats and 2 baby goats.

loans.use: to start a livestock activity by adding more 8 goats to the herd of two.

loans.name: Parul

texts.en:
Parul, 38 years old,  lives in a small village of Falakata in West Bengal. She is a careful mother of two children (one son and one daughter). She is a widow, who unfortunately lost her husband a few years ago. But she has a great determination to provide her children a good education. Thus she works hard to provide every support to her children. Parul runs a clothing business to earn a living for her family. Her son is a student of grade 5.

Parul’s daughter, 16-year-old Anamika, is studying in grade 11 in Khirerkote High School, a local school in Falakata. She has chosen the Arts stream. She is serious about her studies and tries hard to score good marks in her final Board examination. Parul faces difficulties to cover the education expenses of her two children after meeting the household costs with her sole income, yet she is striving to provide uninterrupted education to her children. 

Hence, as a responsible mother, Parul is requesting a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS to bear the educational expenses of her daughter. She plans to pay educational fees, buy study materials, and a bicycle for her daughter, so that she can easily go to school, saving time and conveyance cost. The loan will help this bright young girl continue her education without any obstacles.

Parul and Anamika (in the photo) are grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To cover her daughter's educational expenses in grade 11.

loans.name: Gavrusha

texts.en:
Gavrusha started his meat selling business in the beginning of this year. Now, with the first profit starting to appear, he would like to expand his store and the variety of products that he sells there. 

Gavrusha asks this loan to be able to organize construction and renovation work and expand the store. He needs to purchase materials and furniture for that new part and build a small fast food place. 

He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. 

Gavrusha hopes to receive lenders' support and develop his business. Gavrusha is full of enthusiasm and waits for lenders' support. 

He lives and works in Meghri town with his elderly retired father, wife and 20-year-old son.

loans.use: to pay for renovation and expansion of the store and purchase materials and furniture for it

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared is 47 years old, married, and supports a family of four children. 

He has been operating in motorcycle transport for the last 15 years, earning KES 15,000 per month. 

Jared has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production and supply in the areas for more income gain. 

He plans to use the anticipated profits to educate his children. 

His future hope and dream is to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production and supply in the area for more income gain.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production and supply in the area for more income gain.

loans.name: Emine

texts.en:
Emine is 61 years old and does livestock with her husband to earn a living. She lives on a riverbank in the suburbs of a city in south central Albania. 

In addition to the livestock earnings, she receives a retirement pension of $180/month.  Currently, Emine has 10 sheep and the location of her residence makes it easy for her to take the sheep to graze, as seen in the photograph. While she doesn’t sell any raw milk or dairy products, she does sell roughly 10 baby sheep a year. On the land that she owns, she has some grapevines, orchards and olive groves, and she does sell fruits.

The loan that Emine is applying for will be used to build a stable for the sheep and also a fence around the land.

loans.use: to build a stable for the sheep and a fence around the land

loans.name: Mungu Ni Mwema Group

texts.en:
Suzana (far right) is a member of Mungu Ni Mwema Group, part of Wezesha Project in Uvira, Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. She is 45 years old and the mother of 13 children. She is very thankful for to continue to receive loans that allow her to grow business. One year ago she was at the lowest point, and when she received the loan from Wezesha Project, her life began changing. 

She will use this loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal to sell and she will use the profit to support her 13 children.

loans.use: to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas is aged 47 years, married to Peris and he supports 2 children. He has been a farmer for the last 10 years and the business has been profitable. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers for top dressing and hopes this will enable him to get more crop harvest for sell and make more income to support his family.  He plans to use generated profits to purchase a dairy cow for milk production and educate his children. 

His future hopes are to expand his farming business, make more income and be able to provide the basic needs of his family.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers for top dressing and hopes this will enable him to get more crop harvest for sell and make more income to support his family.

loans.name: Alva Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Alva tiene 53 años de edad, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en una colonia  del municipio de  Trojes,  al Oriente de Honduras, su actividad principal es la elaboracion y venta de rosquillas.
Doña Alva cuenta con  más de 13 años de experiencia, es una persona muy luchadora con deseos de superacion, esta solicitando el prestamo para la compra de harina, soda, aceite, leña, etc. para poder seguir elaborando su porducto los cuales son muy buscados por sus clientes.
Doña Alva esta muy agradesida con Prisma porque ya ha tenido varios prestamos los cuales le han auydado mucho para salir adelante con su familia, uno de sus  sueños es darles una mejor calidad de vida a su familia


Trojes, Honduras, Junio del 2015.
texts.en:
Señora Alva is 53 years old, and she lives with her husband and two children in a community in the municipality of Trojes, in eastern Honduras.  Her principal occupation is making and selling donuts. 

She has more than thirteen years’ experience, and she is a person with a fighting spirit, who wants to succeed. She is requesting the loan to purchase flour, baking soda, oil, firewood, etc., so that she can continue making her products, which are very much sought after by her customers.

Doña Alva is very grateful for Prisma because she has already had several loans that have helped her very much to get ahead, along with her family. One of her dreams is to give her family a better quality of life.

Trojes, Honduras – June, 2015

loans.use: to purchase flour, baking soda, oil, firewood, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfred is 53 years old, married and supports a family of four children. 

He has been operating in his retail shop for the last 26 years, earning KES 15,000 per month. 

Wilfred has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production and supply in the area for more income gain. 

He plans to use the anticipated profits to educate his children. 

His future hope and dream is to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production and supply in the area for more income gain.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is 27 years old, married to Hyline, and supports two children. He has been a dairy farmer for the last eight years. The business earns him KES 11,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase a dairy cow for milk production. This will help him to supply clients daily with a lot of milk and meet their demands for milk. 

He plans to use the profit to repay the loan and to educate his children. His hopes are to expand his business and to eradicate poverty.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is 75 years old and supports two children. 

He has been a dairy farmer selling milk to clients for the last 22 years. The business earns him KES 20,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase a dairy cow for milk production. This will enable him to increase the number of litres of milk supplied to clients daily.

He plans to use the profit to purchase trees and to improve his fishing activities by purchasing more fish and fish feed. 

His hope is to expand his agricultural business.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Tadeus

texts.en:
Tadeus is 44 years old, married to Josephine, and supports a family of six children. He has been practicing farming for the last five years. 

He has applied for his first loan from VisionFund Kenya. He will use it to buy a dairy cow in order to produce milk to sell. By supplying his customers with milk, he will earn more income and be able to support his family. 

He plans to use the anticipated profits to educate his children. His future hopes and dreams are to expand his business, to make more income, and to be financially stable.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey is 53 years old, married, and supports a family of five children. 

He has been practicing tailoring for the last 13 years, earning KES 12,000 per month. 

Geoffrey has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to educate his children. 

His future hope and dream is to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase shoe soles and glue for the repair of client shoes he can meet client and family needs.

loans.name: Gurgen

texts.en:
Gurgen has a newly started business: he is providing car washing service in the center of Sisian town. In his  working garage, Gurgen receives at least 12 cars a day and washs them. He works hard to satisfy customers' demands and does a good job so customers will come back and use the service again. 

Gurgen has applied for this loan to purchase car washing tools and materials needed for the business. The tools which he currently has are not enough for the job, so Gurgen hopes a lot to your support. 

Gurgen has been approved for a loan within the framework of a joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. He hopes to receive Kiva lenders' support and develop his business so his family has better living conditions.

Gurgen lives with his wife and their 6-year-old daughter.

loans.use: to pay for car washing tools and materials needed for the business

loans.name: Alber David

texts.es: Alber emprendió su negocio con la mucha expectativa de mejora su calidad de vida, puesto que sus ingresos no le abastecían para cubrir todos los gastos en el hogar. Él tiene 34 años de edad  y reside en compañía de su cónyuge en un barrio del municipio de Soledad en donde está situado el apartamento que arrienda. Hoy en día está solicitando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, para realizar adecuaciones locativas a su apartamento y así ofrecer una mejor habitabilidad de la vivienda que le permita a sus inquilinos estar en un lugar más confortable.  Esta inversión le permitirá incrementar el canon de arrendamiento y con ello maximizar sus ingresos. Aunque su principal desafío ha sido el escaso capital, esta limitante no ha sido obstáculo para continuar con sus propósitos y su meta a futuro es incrementar sus ingresos para ofrecerle bienestar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Alber began his business with high hopes of improving his standard of living, since his income was not sufficient to cover all the costs at home.  He is 34 years old and lives with his life partner in a town in a neighborhood of the town of Soledad, where the apartment he rents out is located.  Currently he is seeking a Kiva loan, the first application he has made to the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, to remodel the apartment and thus offer more comfortable living space to his tenants.   This loan will allow him to increase the rent he charges and thus increase his income. 

 Although his main challenge has been lack of capital, this limit has not kept Alber from carrying out his purposes.  Alber's goal for the future is to increase his income in order to provide for the well being of his children.

loans.use: to remodel an apartment he rents to others

loans.name: Oswere

texts.en:
Oswere is aged 57 years and supports six children. He has been a shop keeper for the last two years, earning KES 6,000 per month. 

Oswere has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase more stocks of products such as sugar, cooking fat and soap to meet both family and client needs.  He plans to use gained profit to repay the loan and to purchase a dairy cow for milk production so he can supply milk to clients daily. 

Oswere hopes to expand into other business sectors.

loans.use: to purchase more products such as sugar, cooking fat and soap to sell

loans.name: Mosota

texts.en:
Mosota is 27 years and supports two children. For the last two years he has been offering computer services, earning KES 6,000 per month. 

Mosota has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase more stocks of plain paper, a paper cutter and a printer so as to offer better and faster services to clients. He plans to use gained profit to repay the loan and purchase a dairy cow for milk production and chicks for rearing. 

Mosota hopes to expand his business sector and become self-reliant through his business and agricultural activity.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of plain paper, a paper cutter and a printer to offer better and faster services to clients.

loans.name: Artashes

texts.en:
Artashes is construction worker living in Kapan town of Syunik region. He is not married and lives together with his parents. They are elderly retired and Artashes is the main breadwinner in the family.   He has a three years of experience in construction works and due to his hard and responsible work, he has many loyal  clients.
 
Artashes needs some tools and materials to be able to complete current orders, so he decided to take out this loan. Artashes hopes that Kiva lenders will support him with his construction works and help him to purchase tools and materials for construction works. 

Artashes has now been approved for a loan within the framework of joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. He hopes to receive lenders' support and develop his works as a constructor so his parents has better living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for tools and materials for construction works

loans.name: Prene

texts.en:
Prene wants to replace a dairy cow as about a week ago her cow was stolen at night from the stable. " As soon as I woke up I went to the stable as usually to milk the cows and clean the stable, and I became so very upset one I realized that one of my cows was not there. I immediately knew what had happened. My stomach hurt all day and strangely enough, I could not prevent my tears coming down. 

Later in the day, i managed to compose myself. I called the loan officer and told him what had happened. When he said that i could get another loan, I relaxed somehow," said Prene to the branch assistant who interviewed her.

loans.use: to replace a stolen dairy cow with a new one.

loans.name: Nazemse De Yamtenga Group

texts.fr:
Amina est une femme de 35 ans elle est mariée mère de 4 enfants  dont 3 scolarisés.elle vend l'igname depuis 8 ans. le succès dans son entreprise c'est qu'elle n'est pas nouvelle dans la vente  de l'igname, sa manière à elle c'est le respect, son écoute des clients et aussi son amour de son commerce c'est tous ces  atouts qui l'amène à réussir.
Elle a 3 eme crédit et elle rembourse aux dates prévues.
Elle veut acheter des ignames à 50 000fcfa et 75000fca de patate pour revendre.
texts.en:
Amina is a 35-year old woman, married and the mother of four children, all of whom are in school. She has been selling yams for eight years. Her success is due to the fact that she is not new to this business and has a friendly and respectful manner, treating her customers well. She also loves her work. All of these reasons contribute to her success.

Amina is on her third loan and making payment on time. She would like to buy yams for 50,000 West African francs (FCFA) and sweet potatoes for 75,000 FCFA for resale.

loans.use: to buy yams and sweet potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Nicodemus

texts.en:
Nicodemus is 37 years old, married, and supports a family of six children. He has been practicing dairy farming for the last 10 years and earns KES 13,000 per month. 

Nicodemus has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production. He will supply milk to his area for more income. 

He plans to use the anticipated profits to improve his dairy farming. His future hopes and dreams are to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is aged 60 years, married to Roseline and he supports eight children.

He has been a carpenter for the last two years and the business earns him KES 8,000 per month.

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase more stock of timber, a chisel, plumb tool and hammer for making furniture to sell to clients and meet both client and family needs.

He plans to use the gained profit to repay the loan and purchase a dairy cow for milk production and chicks for rearing and also poultry feed.

His hope is to expand his business sector and improve his agricultural activity.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of timber, a chisel, plumb tool and hammer for making furniture to sell to clients and meet both client and family needs.

loans.name: Usha

texts.en:
Thirty-three-year-old married woman Usha lives in the small village of Raychenga in Falakata. She is a mother of two children (one son and one daughter). Usha's 16-year-old daughter reads in grade 12 and her elder son is in college. Usha's husband is engaged in cycle repairing work. Though his income is scanty, he is striving hard to provide an education to his children.

Usha's elder son, Biswajit, is 18 years old and pursuing his Bachelor of Arts from Falakata College. He cherished a dream since his childhood to become a teacher and will teach the poor village children. To fulfill his dream, he strives hard to complete his graduation, scoring good marks. Both Usha and her husband have great expectations for their elder son. They expect he will achieve high educational qualifications to compete with progressive people in social status. But they can't afford the huge educational expenses of their son.

Hence, Usha is requesting a loan from BJS (a Kiva partner) to bear the educational expenses of her son. She plans to pay college fees, buy study materials and engage private tutors for her son. The loan will help this bright young boy to continue his education without any obstacles.

Usha and Biswajit (in the photo) are grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To pay for her son's educational expenses.

loans.name: Hrant

texts.en:
Hrant and his son live and work in Vanadzor town of the Lori region. They both are engaged in transportation work. Using his own truck, Hrant organizes different trips to neighbouring countries and takes different kinds of products there. Hrant's son is a taxi driver and also helps his father with transportation work.

The truck which Hrant currently drives is damaged and needs some renovation work. That's why Hrant is asking Kiva lenders to support him to pay for renovation of the truck and purchase four tires for it to be able to continue transportation services.

Hrant has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. This hardworking and kind man, Hrant, hopes to receive lenders' support and develop his business so his family has better living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for renovation of the truck and purchase four tires for it to be able to continue transportation service.

loans.name: Lakshmi

texts.en:
Thirty-eight-year-old Lakshmi is living in Parengerpar village in Falakata, Alilpurduar district of West Bengal with her family of four. Amongst her two children (a daughter and a son), her elder daughter has recently been admitted into Falakata College for her three-year Bachelor of Arts degree education and her son reads in school. Lakshmi is determined to impart the best education to her children.

Lakshmi’s husband is a fruit vendor in the local market for the four-member family’s livelihood, which is barely enough to cover the household expenses along with educational expenses. Her elder daughter, 17-year-old Supriya, is now in her first year of a Bachelor of Arts degree program. Being a good and studious student, she wants to join the coaching centers to do better in her final exams so that she can do a B. Ed. (Bachelor of Education) later. All the expenses of Supriya’s course fees and the cost of books come up to such a high amount that it is impossible for Lakshmi to afford with her average financial background. So Lakshmi has taken out a loan from BJS, a Kiva partner.

She wants to use the loan to pay her daughter’s college fees and private tuition fees and purchase all necessary educational materials so that Supriya can go ahead with her studies without any interruption. Lakshmi will also buy a bicycle for her daughter to save the time and cost of her conveyance.

Lakshmi and Supriya (in the picture) are grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to bear the education expenses for her daughter’s graduation degree, Bachelor of Arts.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en: Margarita is a 50-year-old married woman and she is the owner of the house where she lives with her family. The place is not finished but Margarita is doing everything she can to complete the construction of her house. This time she needs a loan to pay for the construction of a wall. Margarita now works as a construction assistant and her husband is a mason so the couple will do all the work when they have the time. She hopes you can help her again. In the picture Margarita is at home and behind her there is the place where she and her husband will build the wall.

loans.use: purchase construction materials to finish a room in her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to make home improvements.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 37 years old, married to Everlyne and supports two children. 

He has been involved in farm supplies for the last three years, earning KES 12,000 per month. 

Daniel has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production. 

He plans to use the anticipated profits to improve his farming. 

His future hopes and dreams are to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production.

loans.name: Phol

texts.en:
Phol, 53, lives in Kandal Province, Cambodia. She has eight children.

To make a living and support her family, she manages and operates a farming business on a small rice farmland which is located near her house. So far, she has been in this type of business for more than ten years.

On average, she is able to make an income of USD 6.00 a day.

She wants to improve the general living conditions of the entire family by having a latrine to use, because there is no latrine in her house now. Therefore, she is borrowing a loan from KIVA to build a latrine and buy the facilities.

By doing this, she can help her family members gain access to sanitation, promote their health, and help to lessen environmental deterioration. She is thankful for the loan granted through HKL with a much lower interest rate than other general loan products.

loans.use: to build a latrine

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is 27 years old, married to Divinah and supports two children. 
He has been a dairy farmer for the last seven years and the business earns him KES 10,000 per month. 
He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase a dairy cow for milk production to supply more liters of milk to clients, meeting their demand.  
He plans to use his gained profit to purchase a dairy cow for milk production and repay the loan. 
His hope is to expand his agricultural business and educate his children to higher levels of education.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow for milk production to supply more liters of milk to clients, meeting their demand.

loans.name: Duncan

texts.en:
Duncan is 29 years old, married and supports four children. 

He has been dairy farming for the last three years earning KES 4,500 per month. 

Duncan has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to improve his farming. 

His future hopes and dreams are to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth, 48 years old, from the province of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. Life in the Philippines is quite hard and most families struggle to make ends meet. Being a strong, business-minded woman, she finds ways and means to earn as much as she can to provide for her family's basic needs and to send her daughter to high school.

Elizabeth is thankful that God has blessed her with a general store and a junk shop business. She buys essential food items such as canned goods, coffee, biscuits, beverages and toiletries from wholesalers and then sells them at retail prices. She also buys and collects scrap metal and sells it to foundries. 

To help her expand operations of her store she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan to buy more grocery items such as canned goods, instant noodles, biscuits, bread, eggs, etc. to sell at her small store. Although she finds it hard at times to collect from those who buy on credit, she is still grateful that God provides enough for their basic needs. She is thanking God and you in advance for your good heart and the financial aid that will be given to her. 

Elizabeth dreams that someday she will own a bigger grocery store. She prays that they will have a house of their own. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and it is there where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, beverages and toiletries to sell.

loans.name: Isidro Orlando

texts.es:
Isidro es un pequeño productor en una comunidad rural de Jinotega, dedicado a la caficultura desde hace más de 10 años. Su finca es de 17 manzanas, de las cuales 4 son de café. Su producción anual promedio en los últimos tres años ha sido de 140 quintales de café pergamino. Cuenta con las certificaciones de Fairtrade, UTZ y C.A.F.E. Practices.

Hasta ahora él ha venido enfrentando dificultades en la nutrición de sus plantas, debido a las continuas enfermedades a las que éstas se enfrentan. Su café necesita la implementación de un plan nutricional que le ayude a mejorar su rendimiento y capacidad para resistir las plagas y enfermedades. 

Este año, está solicitando un financiamiento para la compra de insumos agrícolas y pago de mano de obra para el manejo adecuado de su café, con lo cual asegurará una mayor calidad y disminuirá las pérdidas durante el ciclo. Esta inversión le permitirá a Isidro incrementar los rendimientos y obtener mayores ingresos para mejorar las condiciones de su familia y sus colaboradores.
texts.en:
Isidro has worked as a small coffee producer in a rural community of Jinotega for more than ten years. His farm is almost 30 acres, 7 of which are coffee. His average annual production in the last three years has been 6,440 kilograms of coffee in its husk. He has Fair Trade, UTZ and C.A.F.E. Practices certifications.  

Up until now he has had difficulties with the nutrition of his plants, given the continual diseases they face. His coffee plants needs a nutritional plan that helps them improve their yield and their ability to resist pests and diseases.

This year he is asking for a loan to purchase agricultural supplies and to pay for manual labor in order to properly manage his coffee crop, which will ensure better quality and will decrease the losses during the crop cycle. This investment will allow Isidro to increase his yields and obtain better earnings in order to improve his family's conditions, as well as that of his colleagues.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies and pay for manual labor in order to properly manage his coffee crop.

loans.name: Bisakha

texts.en:
Bisakha is a 41-year-old housewife who lives with her husband and children. Her husband Paritosh is engaged in a vegetable business. Both of them have limited education but give full support to their children in their studies. They are blessed with two daughters and one son. Her elder son works in a small company and one of her daughters is married. Her younger daughter, 18-year-old Ratna, reads in grade 11 in ‘Falakata Subhas Girls’ High School’. She has obtained average marks in her previous board examination and wants to work hard for a smooth promotion to the next grade.

The family’s financial condition is not good. Bisakha is facing problems bearing the cost of private tuition for the subjects for her daughter. Ratna needs to purchase books, study materials and the help of private tuition to score good marks in her examination.

For this reason' Bisakha is taking the loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to pay her daughter’s private tuition’s fees, and school fees and purchase books and other study materials for her higher education, which will make her a responsible citizen. Ratna’s aim is to be a nurse in the future and wants to serve poor people. This loan amount will help Ratna to progress towards her goal.

Bisakha and her daughter Ratna (in the photo) are very much pleased with the loan and thank BJS and Kiva from the core of their heart.

loans.use: To cover the educational costs of her daughter.

loans.name: Prembala

texts.en:
Prembala lives in a small village in Falakata. She is 52 years old and blessed with four children (one son and three daughters). She lives with her husband and children. Her one daughter is married; two daughters and her only son are studying. Her husband is engaged in agricultural work and sometimes he also pulls a cycle van for extra income.

Prembala’s 18-year-old daughter Sharmila reads in grade 10 in Falakata Subhash Girls’ High School. Sharmila dreams of passing by scoring good marks in her grade 10 board examination, so she struggles hard to give her best. Unfortunately, the family income is not enough to bear the cost of an ongoing education for Sharmila. So the family needs financial assistance, so that Sharmila can focus on her studies and carry on her education to reach her goals without any anxiety.

So Prembala seeks financial help from BJS (Kiva’s partner). The educational loan will be used to purchase her daughter's educational articles like books and dress and pay the school fees and tuition fees. Prembala hopes the loan will enable her daughter to reach her goal of being a teacher after successfully completing her education.

Prembala and her daughter Sharmila (in the photo) express their gratitude to their generous lenders.

loans.use: To afford all of her daughter's schooling fees.

loans.name: Matapa

texts.en:
Matapa is single and she is  27-years-old. She runs a small business of selling taro and banana in her village to earn a living.

Matapa requested a loan to buy taro roots (seedlings), banana tubes (seedlings), a wheelbarrow, a rake, a shovel, a water tank, and hand gloves to help her run her business.

She hopes to use her profit to expand her business and provide for her family's needs. She became a member of SPBD in 2013.

loans.use: to buy taro roots (seedlings), banana tubes (seedlings), a wheelbarrow, a rake, a shovel, a water tank, and hand gloves

loans.name: N4K4Lsơn-Solidarity Borrowers Group

texts.en:
Mrs Hiên is 36 years old and she is married.She has had a retail business selling rice for 6 years. Hiên lives in Bim Son town, a semi-urban town in Thanh Hoa province.
Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover this job is unstable.

The main hardship that Hiên faces is lack of capital.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice to resell.
She is a reputable person in the community.

Although this is Hiên first loan with Thanh Hoa microfinance institution, every members agreed to vote her to be the leader of "N4K4LSơn-Solidarity borrowers" group.
With her business profit, Hiên hopes for her business to do well, for her children to do well in school, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase more rice to resell

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 54 years old, married to Theodora and supports a family of 10 children. He has been practicing dairy farming for the last 8 years and it has been profitable. 

He will be using the loan to buy a dairy cow and dairy feeds and hopes this will enable him to get more milk for sell and be able to support his family. 
He plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate his children. 

His future hopes are to improve his dairy farming, make more income and support his family.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and dairy feeds and hopes this will enable him to get more milk to selll and be able to support his family.

loans.name: Mehriban

texts.en: Mehriban is 45 years old and married with two kids. She is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with her family in the Bilasuvar region. Mehriban is a strong and intelligent woman. Like all other women, she loves her family and tries her best to take care of their needs. Her husband, who is a merchant, doesn’t earn enough income, and his salary isn't enough to meet the family's needs. Unfortunately Mehriban can't work because she is ill. She requires funds for her illness to be cured. Mehriban is very hopeful and believes that Kiva lenders will show their best support to her.

loans.use: to be treated for her illness.

loans.name: Yuvinalis

texts.en:
Yuvinalis is aged 63 years, married to Monica and he supports six children.He has been a dairy farmer for the last one year and the business earns him KES 7,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase a dairy cow for milk production so as to enable him supply more number of litres of milk to clients daily and meet both family and client needs.  

He plans to use gained profit to repay the loan and purchase chicks for keeping. His hope is to expand his agricultural sector and be a large scale farmer.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow for milk production so as to enable him supply more number of litres of milk to clients daily and meet both family and client needs.

loans.name: Roman

texts.en:
Roman is from Vanadzor town where he lives with his parents and sister. Roman has been a micro bus driver for over a year. The microbus currently needs a renovation and new tires so Roman decided to take out the loan. He hopes for lenders' support to allow him to continue his business and earn income for his family. 
Roman has now been approved for a loan within the framework of joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products.

loans.use: to pay for renovation of the damaged parts of the car and to buy tires for it

loans.name: Chandana

texts.en:
Chandana is a 32-year-old rural woman from a small village Purba Magurmari in Dhupguri. She lives there with her husband and three children. Her husband Dinabandhu works in a press and his monthly income is too limited to cover the education costs of his children after managing the household needs. 

Chandana’s eldest child Dipankar, a 16-year-old boy, studies at Dhupguri High School (HS) in grade 11. He is a serious and meritorious boy who was promoted to grade 11 with good marks. Dipankar’s ambition is to be a school teacher in future. Now he wants a good private tutor for English and Geography so that he would score better in his coming board examination. His parents try their level best to make their children well-educated. 

Chandana has decided to provide a good tutor to her eldest son but it will be possible only if she can get some financial assistance. That is why she has applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase Dipankar’s educational equipment, pay his school fees, private tuition fees, etc. She hopes that this loan amount will provide a good support to continue her son’s education further and fulfill her son’s dream.

Chandana and Dipankar (as seen in the picture) thank their generous lenders.

loans.use: To cover her son’s education expenses in grade 11.

loans.name: Kloant

texts.en:
Kloant is a 29-year-old rural married man and a father of a 4 and 2 years old. About three years ago he started a carpentry activity and since then it has been some steady growth in it.  His wife is a stay at-home mom thus she receives no income from employment and also they own no land where they could plant something.

 “I learned the skills of this profession from my dad. At first I doubted myself and my capabilities, but I have done well so far and I’m glad I started the activity because has earned me an income that we wouldn’t otherwise,” said Kloant.  He is photographed in the carpentry shop that is located in his village of residence.  

The loan he is requesting from you will be used to buy materials and tools for the profession.

loans.use: to buy tools and materials for the carpentry shop he is running all on his own

loans.name: Dulali

texts.en:
Dulali is 40 years old. She lives in Falakata, Alipurduar district of West Bengal. Her family consists of her husband and two daughters. Dulali is a homemaker and her husband is associated with a clothing business. He sells varieties of clothing to his neighbors, relatives and friends but the income is barely enough to cover the household expenses along with the children’s education cost because he is the only source of income.

Dulali’s 16-year-old daughter Piya is a student of grade 11 in Falakata Subhash Girls’ High School in Arts. She is an average student and has obtained passing marks in the secondary Board examination. Now she needs good private coaching for her grade 11 education. As it is difficult for Dulali to manage all the school fees and the cost of books for her daughter, she is requesting a loan from BJS ( Kiva's partner) to continue her daughter’s education further.

She will pay Piya’s school fees and private tuition fees and purchase books, uniforms and other necessary study materials for her with the loan money. The loan will help Dulali to support her daughter for her further education without any financial constraints.

Dulali and Piya (as in the photo) convey their gratitude to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase study materials and pay the fees for her daughter’s education.

loans.name: Naftal

texts.en:
Naftal is 34 years old, married to Janet and supports three children. He has been a dairy farmer for the last three years and the business earns him KES 23,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase a dairy cow for milk production to increase the liters of milk supplied to clients daily. 

Naftal plans to use his gained profit to educate his children and repay the loan. His hope is to expand his agricultural business.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow for milk production to increase the liters of milk supplied to clients daily.

loans.name: Yesu Ni Jibu Group

texts.en:
Yesu ni jibu is the group from Uvira. Woman from this group are all hardworking women and they finished repaying their last loan on time. Now they are requesting another loan. 

Viviane (seen far left) will use her loan to purchase more clothes to sell. She is a very driven and industrious woman. She has a clothing and sandal business, she and her 2 children depend on the income from this job. 

She is grateful in advance for the support and trust that Wezesha project continue to put in her.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Fane

texts.en:
Fane is 46 years old, married and supports a family of five children.

She has been operating her retail shop for the last eight years earning KES 8,000 per month.

Fane has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production to supply her shop for more income gain.

She plans to use the anticipated profits to educate her children.

Her future hopes and dreams are to be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production to supply her shop for more income gain.

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence is aged 60 years, married to Moraa and he supports five children.

He has been making and selling bricks for the last eight years and the business earns him KES 24,000 per month.

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase iron sheets and nails for making a roof to keep the already made bricks safe from bad weather.

He plans to use the gained profit to purchase a dairy cow for milk production and also purchase cereals such as maize and beans to sell to clients in the market.

His hope is to expand his business sectors and earn more income.

loans.use: to purchase iron sheets and nails for making a roof to keep the already made bricks safe from bad weather.

loans.name: Naira

texts.en:
Naira is a 55-year-old, married woman. She lives with her husband Merab in Batumi district.  Merab teaches mathematics at university and has a monthly income. Naira is unemployed and wants to open a general store. 

The StartUp program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan for purchasing a stock of products to sell in the store. She will pay a lease for a general store. Naira is very hardworking woman and hopes that the business will be profitable. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to open a general store and generate stable income.

loans.name: Simak

texts.en:
Simak is young businessman from Vanadzor town. He lives with his wife and runs a bakery. His business is going well and Simak is very proud that he was able to continue his parents' work successfully. 
Simak now asks for this loan to invest some funds into his bakery and make improvements. He plans to purchase 30 packs of flour and renovate the car which he uses to deliver the bread to stores. Simak has now been approved for a loan within the framework of joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. Simak hopes to receive lenders' support and sustain his bakery to provide a better life for his wife.

loans.use: to pay for 30 packs of flour and renovate the car which he uses to deliver bread to stores

loans.name: Surati

texts.en:
Surati, 35 years old, is the mother of three children (two sons and one daughter). She lives in a small village of Falakata. In spite of having only primary education, she is highly interested to provide her children a good education. The three of them are regular good students in grade 11, grade 7, and grade 5.

Surati is a housewife and her husband is a driver. Her elder son Samaresh is a student in grade 11. He is 16 years old and studies in Falakata High School.  His father is the only earner of the family, so his parents are facing difficulty in paying for his educational expenses. Samaresh is sincere about his studies and school curriculum. Surati has been unable to take care of all the things he needs, to continue his studies. 

Thus Surati applied for an educational loan. She thanks BJS (Kiva’s partner) for helping her; this  loan amount will resolve her anxiety. She will use the loan to buy education materials and will also pay the tuition fees for her son Samaresh.
 
Surati hopes this educational support will give a boost in her son’s education.  So Surati and Samaresh (as seen in the picture) are now very happy by getting the loan from BJS and Kiva and both of them are thankful to the lenders.

loans.use: To cover the educational expenses of her son.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn is from San Miguel, Bohol. She is 38 years old and has two teen-age children. For six years, she has been operating a sari-sari (general) store  in her home. She sell items like noodles, canned goods, items in sachet like coffee, shampoo, bath soap, detergent powder and chips. She is asking for a loan to buy sugar, noodles, soap and cigarettes. In the future, she aspires to expand her business for more income to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy sugar, noodles, soap and cigarettes

loans.name: Aires

texts.en: Aires is from the community of Bien Undio, Bohol. She is 29 years old and married to a fisherman. Aside from helping her husband in their fishing business, she also operates a sari-sari (general) store. She is asking for a loan to buy adhesive and paint, to redeem jewelry at the pawn shop and to buy stock for her store like canned goods, noodles, seasonings and toiletries. Aires and her husband work hard so they can build a better future.

loans.use: to buy adhesive and paint, to redeem jewelry at the pawn shop and to buy stock for her store like canned goods, noodles, seasonings and toiletries

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma, 45 years old, is a restaurant owner from San Miguel, Bohol. She works hard for her three children, ages 14, 15 and 17. She is asking for a loan to buy stock for her restaurant such as vegetables, fruit, beef, pork, spoons, forks, chairs and a wok. With these purchases, she can cook more dishes to increase her profitability.
Guillerma is eager to learn to cook more dishes so she can make her business more successful and attractive to her customers.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, fruit, beef, pork, spoons, forks, chairs and a wok

loans.name: Armen

texts.en:
Armen already paid off his first Kiva loan and greatly hopes to receive the second one. Armen lives in Ddmashen village of Gegharkunik region. He lives with his parents, his wife and his three children. 

In order to be able to sustain his family’s needs, Armen works very hard and all day long on his farm, where he has cows, calves, sheep, pigs and chickens. With the help of his wife, Armen sells his farm’s milk, meat, cheese, butter, curd and eggs. His plot of land gives a harvest of potatoes, greens, tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage and garlic. All these products are also used for his family use. 

Armen asks for his second Kiva loan with plans to increase his farm cattle, so he wants to buy a calf, a horse, and also a rake for his agricultural activities.

loans.use: to buy a calf, a horse and also a rake for his agricultural activities

loans.name: Pabita Bala

texts.en:
Pabita is a rural housewife of 36 years, living in Magurmari village in Dhupguri with her family of four. Her husband Kshitish is engaged in agriculture. She is blessed with two children (a daughter and a son). Pabita studied only up to grade 5 due to her family's financial insufficiency.  So she is determined to impart the best education to her children.

Her daughter, 18-year-old Mitali, is pursuing her Bachelor's education from Sukanta Mahabidyalay.  Being meritorious, she is studying for a Bachelor of Arts in 2nd year. But now she wants to enroll in coaching classes to do better in her final exams. All the expenses of her  daughter’s  course fee and the cost of books  have come to such a high amount that it becomes impossible for Pabita to afford with her poor financial background. 

So Pabita has taken out a loan from BJS, a Kiva partner. She wants to utilize the loan to pay her daughter’s college fees, private tuition fees and purchase all necessary educational materials, so that her daughter can go ahead with her studies without any interruption.

Pabita and her daughter (in the picture) are very much grateful to BJS and Kiva for their loan.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's education expenses for her graduation degree.

loans.name: Rafael Bernabe

texts.en:
Rafael Bernabe is 27 years old. He graduated from college as an engineer. He works in the systems department of a company, but recently took charge of a family business that is a stationery and office supplies store located inside a Mexico City Market. 

The business has been in operation for 25 years, but his parents recently retired and he took charge of the business. He is asking for a loan to buy some inventory at volume at get large discounts. It also will help him prepare for the back to school sales season. His goal is to grow the business.

loans.use: to buy products for his stationery and office supplies store.

loans.name: Shefali

texts.en:
Shefali is a 36-year-old lady from Falakata. She is married to Dipak, aged 44 years.  Both the husband and wife have limited education. They are blessed with two sons. Their elder son is studying in college and the younger one is in grade 9. Shefali's husband runs a puffed rice shop, which does not provide them sufficient income to run the family well.

Shefali's younger son, 13-year-old Dip, is in grade 9. He is a smart and brilliant boy and scores very good marks every year.  Shefali always worries about making enough money and saving some of it for her children's education. Every year she faces the problem of making ends meet at the beginning of the school year for the additional expenditures that are needed to cover school fees, uniform, and books.

Thus Shefali has taken a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS, to pay for her son's tuition fees and other school expenses and to purchase necessary articles like books, pens, pencils, a geometry box, a uniform, etc.  With this loan she can accommodate all these expenses. She aims to see her son leading a decent life with a good education.

In this picture, Shefali and her son Dip, will be benefited from the loan. Both of them are grateful to BJS and Kiva for this educational loan.

loans.use: To pay for her son’s 9th grade education.

loans.name: Ana Cristina

texts.en:
Ana Cristina is 24 years old and works with her husband selling seeds, chilies and other food items in a Mexico City Market. She says that she started the business two years ago with the goal to become independent and able to support her new family. 

She is asking for a loan to buy more products for her business. She says that in the past she has taken loans and always repaid them on time. She has also been able to build two rooms in her in-law’s house. Her goal is to build her own house.

loans.use: to buy seeds and other primary items such as dry chilies.

loans.name: Fatema

texts.en:
Fatema is a 29-year-old rural housewife from a small village called Baganbari in Falakata. She lives there with her husband and three children (a son and two daughters). Two of her children are attending school. Fatema and her husband are illiterate, though they can sign their name only; their first priority is to provide good education to their children.

Fatema is a homemaker while her husband makes wooden furniture to earn their livelihood. His monthly income is inconsistent and insufficient for the family of five. Almost his whole earning is spent for household expenses, so the education expenses of his children create a burden on him. But Fatema’s only son, 12-year-old Ashadul, is a bright student in grade 8 in Baganbari Jr. High School. He scored good marks in the last year final examination and always tries to score better because his aim is to be a doctor in future. 

Being a dedicated and responsible mother, Fatema tries her level best to continue her son’s education at any cost. So she is seeking a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase all educational equipment and pay all fees for her beloved son. The loan amount will enable Fatema to give moral support to her son Ashadul for making his dream come true.

Fatema and her son (as seen in the picture) are grateful to Kiva and BJS.

loans.use: To cover the cost of her son’s education for grade 8.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana lives with her son at her own house.  She is a schoolteacher.  Ana needs a loan to buy construction materials such as concrete.  She is paying for the repairs at her home. 

Ana is giving her best to complete the construction of her house and she hopes you can help her. She works hard, she is healthy, and she wants to give her son a better life.  In the picture, Ana is at her house. As you can see, the place needs a lot of work.

loans.use: to buy construction materials such as concrete.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a widow and she is still living with her son. She is healthy now, and she needs a loan to start a business.  She wants to open a little restaurant and she needs some money to complete her investment. Since she has saved some money, she will buy meat and soft drinks. 

Maria also is still working at an insurance company.  She hopes you can help her again. She still has plans to move to her own place, and in that way she won t be giving her son any trouble.  Maria is a good cook, so she has a lot of hope for her business.

loans.use: to open a little restaurant.

loans.name: Nadine

texts.en:
Nadine is a 23-year-old single woman, living with her parents and five siblings. She cooperates financially with her father to be able to pay the heavy life expenses. 

She has operated with her parents a grocery store since 2004 and now she became responsible for the work. Her shop is situated next to her house, where she welcomes customers from different areas and villages to buy her fresh goods. 

Today she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Vitas. s.a.l. to increase her grocery store’s inventory. She states that the loan will certainly help her extend her trade and increase her income by a large percentage. 

In the future, she plans to borrow more Kiva loans to further develop her work.

loans.use: to increase her grocery store’s inventory

loans.name: Cleotilde

texts.en:
Cleotilde is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines.  She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Cleotilde has been in this business for five years. She also earns more income from raising pigs. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Yehowa Dzi Mikwelo Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of eight members and are on their fifth loan with ID-Ghana. The members' businesses include selling smoked fish, clothes, sauce pans, local dishes, underwear, kids dresses, necklaces, earrings, herbal medicine and jeans.

The loan they are requesting will benefit micro-entrepreneurs including Monica. She states that eight years ago, she joined ID-Ghana at the invitation of her sister, who was already a client. Now, Monica has a business selling underwear and she learned this trade from her sister six years ago.

The present loan is for raising capital for Monica to purchase panties, brassieres, trousers, shirts and polo-shirts from the wholesale market in Accra and later sell the goods door-to-door. This business allows her to generate income to support her family, as she is married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about ID-Ghana, Monica replied that she likes the training and the savings the institution provides.

loans.use: To purchase panties, brassieres, trousers, shirts and polo-shirts from the wholesale, market in Accra.

loans.name: Romulo

texts.en:
Romulo is 69 years old, widowed, and has four children of adult age. He lives in Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. He has been a farmer in their place for more than 40 years. Through his farming activity, he is able to provide for the needs of his family. 

Romulo learned about Paglaum MPC and the financial and insurance services it extends to its members. He decided to sign up for membership and avail financial and insurance services. He has successfully repaid his loans with no records of default. Recently, he availed another loan in the amount of PHP 7,000 to purchase bags of fertilizer for his farm.

loans.use: to purchase bags of fertilizer.

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita has the expertise in hog raising, which she learned from her parents. She is 46 years old, married, and has four children of school age.  She lives in Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She signed up for membership with Paglaum MPC in 2009. She is glad that the cooperative has been helping her with her financial needs, especially on her hog raising business. 

Recently, she availed another loan of PHP 14,900 to purchase bags of animal feed and animal vitamins for her hog raising business. She is hopeful that she will succeed in this business, so that she can continue to provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase bags of animal feed and animal vitamins for her hog raising business.

loans.name: Iti

texts.en:
Iti is a 32-year-old rural woman who lives in Falakata, Alipurduar district of West Bengal. Her family consists of her husband and two daughters. Two of her daughters are studying in school. Iti is a homemaker, and her husband is associated with a car-renting business. His monthly income is irregular, and he is the sole source of the family’s income, so to afford his children’s education cost along with the household expenses is quite difficult for him.

Iti’s 16-year-old daughter Moumita is a student of grade 11 in Falakata Girls’ High School in Arts stream. She is an average student and has obtained average marks in the secondary board examination. Now she needs good private coaching for her grade 11 education. Due to the inconsistent income, Iti fails to manage all the educational fees and the cost of books for her elder daughter Moumita, and thus she is requesting a loan from BJS (Kiva's partner) to continue her daughter’s education further.

She will pay her daughter’s school fees and tuition fees, and purchase books, uniforms and other necessary study materials with the loan money. The loan will help Iti to support her daughter in passing out of the Higher Secondary level education without any financial constraints.

Iti and Moumita (in the photo) convey their gratitude to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase study materials and pay the fees for her daughter’s education.

loans.name: Rena

texts.en:
Rena is 50 years old and lives in Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married with four children of school age. Rena is engaged in managing a sari-sari store and a buy-and-sell business that gives her earnings of approximately PHP 20,000 each month doing this type of business activity. 

She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional inventories such as consumable goods and clothing for her buy-and-sell business.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventories such as consumable goods and clothing for her retail buy-and-sell business.

loans.name: Mausumi

texts.en:
Twenty-six-year-old Mausumi lives in a remote village of Falakata in the Alipurduar district. She is a housewife, and her husband is involved with a small business. They are blessed with two children (one son and one daughter). Her daughter reads in grade six, and her son is a toddler.

Her husband’s monthly income is hardly enough to cover the educational expenses of their daughter. But, she desires that her daughter does not face any obstacle in receiving education.

Mausumi's daughter, 10-year-old Amrita, is now in grade six. She is a student of Falakata Girls’ High School. She is a girl of strong determination, and she is also very studious. If she could get private tuition, she could do much better in her final examination. She wants to be a nurse in the future.

Mausumi learned about BJS (Kiva's partner) and applied for a loan from BJS for her daughter's uninterrupted education. With the loan amount, she will pay the private tuition fees and school fees, and purchase necessary articles like books, notebooks, pen geometry box, uniforms, etc. for the continuous education of her daughter.

Mausumi and her daughter Amrita are very much grateful to the lenders for this loan.

loans.use: to bear the costs of her daughter's continuous education.

loans.name: Joaquin

texts.en: Joaquin is 27 years old and describes himself as hard working and responsible. He has worked in a company that organizes events for people and companies. He says that he has been working since he graduated from college, but has not been able to save money because he helps his parents with the home expenses. Joaquin is asking for a loan to pay for college fees related to title paper work, paying these will permit him to finally get his degree and hopefully grow professionally.

loans.use: to pay for graduation expenses and finally get his college title.

loans.name: Maria Consuelo

texts.es:
